body: Theater ''ELLIE AND THE PRINCE,'' a modern version of the Cinderella tale, using Beatles music, presented by Downtown Art, 64 East Fourth Street, East Village. Fridays and Saturdays at 7:30 p.m. and Sundays at 2 p.m. through Jan. 11 (except Dec. 26 to 28). Tickets, $5; 18 and under, $4. Reservations: (212) 505-0835. JIM WEST IN ''MORE AESOP'S
title: SPARE TIMES; FOR CHILDREN

body: Maybe you can't judge a book by its cover, but it sure looks as if you can judge New Yorkers by their dogs. A New York Times analysis of dog licensing data (yes, we took the time to do this) from recent statistics collected by the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene shows that Hispanics are more likely than whites or blacks to own
title: New York's Top Dog? It Depends on the ZIP Code

body: A suspicious fire late Wednesday night gutted a six-story building that is home to apartments and a restaurant and nightclub central to the Russian immigrant community on the Brighton Beach boardwalk, officials said yesterday. As flames licked the slats of the boardwalk and melted the restaurant's glass facade, a daring rescue unfolded inside, with
title: Fire Guts Hub for Russians in Brighton Beach

body: The view was nearly perfect: a sun-filled sky spread across Coney Island's surf and dipped into the glistening ocean. But then, like a crack running through an old photograph, a bright orange line ruined the picture. The line, a string of warning flags, ran the length of the beach to keep hopeful swimmers out of polluted waters on one of New York
title: A Day to Wet a Toe or Two, but Not Much More

body: FURTH--Enrique. Born August 4, 1928 in Buenos Aires, Argentina, died suddenly July 11, 2003 at his home in Brooklyn, NY. Survived by his three children, Susan of Bedford, NY, Hugo (Lori) of Manhattan Beach, CA, and Elizabeth of Brooklyn, NY; brother, Tomas, of Buenos Aires, former wife, Ada of Playa Del Rey, CA, and long-time friend Randi Baker of
title: Paid Notice: Deaths FURTH, , ENRIQUE

author: Steve Kurutz is a staff writer for Details magazine.
body: THE Belt Parkway, which stretches for 36 miles from Owls Head Park in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, to Long Island, is a road as bold and monolithic as New York City itself. The highway, which was built by Robert Moses, is lined with concrete barriers and colossal traffic jams on weekends. Driving the Belt is like skirting along the very heart of urbanism.
title: In the Still of the Night

body: MICHAEL A. REBELL, executive director of the Campaign for Fiscal Equity, does not seem the type to do the frug. (That's a dance, for the boogie-challenged among you.) But Mr. Rebell, a 60-year-old lawyer, is giving an impromptu demonstration, waving his hands high, wiggling in a chair, recalling how he frugged to ''Celebration'' by Kool and the
title: PUBLIC LIVES; A Child of the 60's, and a Keeper of the Faith

body: The aircraft carrier Abraham Lincoln is finally coursing home from the war in Iraq, bringing with it an airman whose Brooklyn home is now filled with relief. The anxiety of a worried family -- the cigarettes, the acting out in school, the tears in front of the television news -- is drifting away. The story is familiar, almost trite. But the
title: Fear for a Navy Son, and for Fellow Muslims; Viewing Images of a War They Hate, a Brooklyn Family Is Proud and Sad

body: STEIN - Jacob (Jack) of Brooklyn, NY died Tuesday, April 8 at the age of 90. Jack was a Navy Veteran of WWII, retired attorney, former secretary of Manhattan Beach Jewish Center, past commander and associate chairman for senior citizens of the Jewish War Veterans. He is survived by his loving wife of 63 years, Mathilda, his sons Mark and Allan and
title: Paid Notice: Deaths STEIN, JACOB (JACK)

body: THE neighborhood of Sheepshead Bay, which struggled in the 1980's and early 90's, has been making a comeback in recent years. So too, it appears, is the fish for which the bay is named. The creature whose face and teeth are said to look like those of a sheep is found nowadays in more southern waters, but lately there have been rumors that
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn; Where Water Is Big Part of Community

body: To set foot outdoors yesterday was to receive an unexpected present gift-wrapped in sunshine. Perhaps no one was as taken aback, however, as a tiny Yorkshire terrier named Choco, who found himself plopped down on John Street in Lower Manhattan by his owner, Sheena Kim. Ms. Kim bought Choco in November but said she had not taken him out of her
title: Spring? No, but Only Calendar Can Tell the Difference

body: Events ''PIPES AND POTATOES: BROOKLYN'S IRISH FARMERS,'' a free event celebrating St. Patrick's Day with music, dancing, food and crafts demonstrations. Tomorrow from noon to 4 p.m. at the Wyckoff Farmhouse Museum, 5816 Clarendon Road at Ralph Avenue, Flatbush, Brooklyn. Information: (718) 629-5400. ST. PATRICK'S DAY AT THE CHILDREN'S MUSEUM OF
title: SPARE TIMES; FOR CHILDREN

body: The intricate geography of income difference in New York City is something Chastity Davis absorbed early, growing up in the 1980's in a tenement apartment in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, on a block of mostly brick row houses flanked by public housing projects at either end. At the neighborhood elementary school, Ms. Davis's friends were from the
title: Here, Poverty And Privilege Are Neighbors; Income Gaps Are a Source Of Resentment and Guilt

body: ROZMAN-Sol. Age 93. Philanthropist, philatelist, Judaica collector, member Collectors Club, member Manhattan Beach Jewish Center, founder of the Great Synagogue in Jerusalem, founder Sunrise Jewish Center, Sunrise, FL, member Lubavitch, supporter Yeshiva Ohel Moshe. Loving father of Rita Birnbaum (Stanley) and Beverly S. Goldfarb (Dr. Herbert).
title: Paid Notice: Deaths ROZMAN, SOL

body: ONCE, the folk music clubs in and around New York City were numerous and legendary: Folk City, the Speakeasy or Cafe a Go Go, to name a few. The rooms were intimate, the performances spontaneous and the musician on stage might be either the next Bob Dylan or Dylan himself. Now the legacy of these clubs lives on mainly in memory, with a few
title: Now Playing in Pawling
